TEXT.P: Exercise alone was enough to prevent the degeneration of brain cells in rats with Parkinson's disease, University of Pittsburgh researchers report.

The loss of cells that produce the neurotransmitter dopamine causes the telltale tremors, rigid and slow movements of Parkinson's. The researchers gave rats a toxin that induces Parkinson's and then counted dopamine-producing cells in the brains of rats that had exercised for seven days and those that had not.

The rats that had been exercised had lost significantly fewer neurons than the sedentary rats. The rats also had significantly greater amounts of the protein GDNF, which the University of Pittsburgh scientists speculate may protect brain cells from oxygen damage produced by the disease.
The researchers have launched a small pilot study to see if regular exercise can slow the progression of Parkinson's in people.
